caseTitle: MISCELLANY-AT-LAW A TALK BY JUSTICE J N K TAYLOR, JUSTICE OF
summary: This 1987–1988 address by Justice J.N.K. Taylor, a Supreme Court Justice of Ghana, explores the tension between traditional Anglo-Ghanaian common law principles and emerging socialist legality during a period of political flux under the Provisional National Defence Council (PNDC) regime. Justice Taylor critiques the rise of 'socialist legality,' where state or party policy supersedes codified law, undermining judicial independence and the rule of law. He highlights public misinterpretation of legal principles, exemplified by backlash against his comments on 'kalabule' (profiteering), and expresses concern over the establishment of parallel public tribunals that bypass traditional courts. The speech underscores a deepening schism within the legal profession, with some lawyers participating in these tribunals despite the Ghana Bar Association's opposition, threatening the coherence and integrity of Ghana’s legal system.
verdict: No judicial verdict; this is a judicial address analyzing legal and systemic dilemmas.
citations: Speech to University of Ghana Law Students, 14 March 1983
rationaleHighlights: Law must not operate in a vacuum but respond to political context.
Socialist legality risks subordinating law to party will.
Judicial independence is essential to prevent arbitrary power.
The concept of 'kalabule' was misapplied without legal controls.
Public tribunals threaten the unity of the judiciary.
Legal professionals face ethical dilemmas under revolutionary regimes.
Common law tradition protects individual rights against state overreach.
Miscommunication and political pressure inhibit free legal discourse.
confidenceNotes: High confidence in factual extraction; source is a verbatim judicial speech with clear attribution. No adversarial judgment rendered; content is analytical and reflective of legal concerns during Ghana's PNDC era.
